content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Amy Richards: Well, I was born in Des Moines, Iowa, and I've lived here most of my life. I grew up in a small, close-knit neighborhood on Prairie Lane, where everyone knew each other. My parents were both hardworking people—my dad worked at a local factory, and my mom was a school secretary. We weren't wealthy, but we were comfortable, and I always felt lucky to have both of them around. I was the kind of kid who loved reading and spent a lot of time at the library. I was pretty shy as a teenager, but I found my confidence through school activities and eventually through my studies. I went to college right after high school, got my bachelor's degree in business administration, and then landed a job at a local company. I met my husband, Mark, while we were both working at the same office—actually, he was my coworker for a few years before we started dating. We got married a few years ago, and we've been trying to build a life together here in Iowa. It's not always easy, but I love the stability and the community feel of this place.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Amy Richards: Yes, there was definitely a crossroads. After high school, I had two main options: go to college or take a job right away. My parents were supportive either way, but I felt like if I didn't go to college, I might be stuck in the same cycle they were in—working hard but not necessarily moving up. I applied to a few schools, and I got into a state university with a scholarship, which made it possible for me to go. I remember sitting at my kitchen table, staring at the acceptance letter, and thinking about how different my life could be if I took that step. I chose to go, and that decision changed everything. It opened doors I never knew existed, and it was the first time I really felt like I had control over my future. I don't think I would be where I am today without that choice.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Amy Richards: I think for me, it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. I remember talking to my mom that night, and she said something that stuck with me—'If you don't take this chance, you'll always wonder what could have been.' That really made me think. I didn't just decide to go to college because I wanted to get out of my parents' situation, though that was part of it. I wanted to learn, to grow, and to have more options. I remember feeling a mix of fear and excitement, like I was stepping into the unknown, but I knew it was the right path for me. I think that moment was the first time I truly felt like I was taking ownership of my life, and that sense of agency has stayed with me ever since.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Amy Richards: Absolutely. My high school guidance counselor, Mrs. Thompson, was a huge influence on me during that time. She saw potential in me that I didn't always see in myself, and she encouraged me to apply to college. She even helped me fill out the applications and find scholarships. Without her support, I might have been too scared to take that step. I think it's important for people to have mentors or resources that can help them see possibilities they might not have considered on their own. I try to pay that forward now by volunteering at the local library and mentoring high school students who are thinking about their futures. It's a small way to give back, but it means a lot to me.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Amy Richards: Yes, I'm married to Mark, and we have a daughter named Lily who's four years old. Mark and I met at the company I worked for after college, and we've been together for almost seven years. He's a software engineer, and while our careers are different, we both value hard work and family. Lily is a bright, curious child who loves drawing and storytelling—just like I did when I was younger. Being a mother has been one of the most rewarding experiences of my life, though it's also come with its own set of challenges. I've had to balance my job, parenting, and trying to keep our home life stable. Mark is a great partner, and we both make an effort to be involved in Lily's life as much as possible. I think having a family has given me a new perspective on life, and it's reinforced the importance of the choices I made earlier on, like pursuing education and building a stable career.

Going through those interview questions felt like revisiting key moments that shaped who I am today. Starting with the story of my life reminded me of how much my roots in Des Moines have influenced my values and the sense of community I cherish. When I talked about the crossroads after high school, it brought back the emotional weight of that decision and how it set me on a path I never could have imagined. Reflecting on whether it was a conscious choice or something that 'just happened' made me realize how much intention and support went into that moment. Thinking about the people who helped me, like Mrs. Thompson, reminded me of the importance of guidance and how I now try to be that support for others. And finally, talking about my family today gave me a sense of pride and gratitude for the life I've built with Mark and Lily. It all ties together to show how my past choices, the people who supported me, and the life I've created are all part of the same story.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Amy Richards: My immediate family includes my parents, John and Linda Richards, and my younger brother, Ethan. My parents are still living in Des Moines, and we stay in close contact. They've always been a big part of my life, even though they've had their own challenges over the years. My dad retired from the factory a few years ago, and he's been helping out around the house, fixing things and gardening. My mom still volunteers at the community center, which is something she's always loved doing. She's a very giving person, and I think that's one of the reasons I grew up valuing service and community so much. Ethan is 28 now and works in sales for a company in Chicago. We don't see each other as often as we'd like, but we keep in touch through calls and visits. He's always been the more adventurous one in the family, and I admire how he's carved out his own path. I think our family dynamic has always been one of support and love, even when things got tough. I'm grateful for them, and I know they're proud of the life I've built with Mark and Lily.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Amy Richards: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Sarah, who I met in college. We were in the same business program, and we've been close ever since. She's the kind of person who always knows how to make me laugh, even on my toughest days. After college, she moved to Minneapolis for a job, but we still keep in touch. She's married now with two kids, and while our lives have taken different paths, I still value our friendship. Then there's my coworker, Tom, who's been a great friend and confidant at work. He's one of the few people who can keep up with my sometimes chaotic schedule as a mom and a full-time employee. I also have a few friends from church, and they've been a big support system for me, especially since becoming a mother. I think it's important to have people in your life who you can rely on, who challenge you, and who remind you of the good things in life. Those relationships have been just as important as the ones with my family in shaping who I am today.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Amy Richards: I live in a quiet neighborhood on the east side of Des Moines, just a few blocks from the park where Lily loves to play. It's a mix of older homes and some newer developments, and there's a real sense of community here. We have a neighborhood association that organizes events like a fall festival and a summer movie night in the park. I really appreciate how friendly the people are here—everyone waves when they see you, and if you're ever in need of help, someone is always willing to lend a hand. Our street is lined with trees, and there's a small community garden where some of the neighbors grow vegetables and flowers. It's a peaceful place to raise a family, and I feel lucky to be part of it. I think the kind of life I wanted for Lily—stable, safe, and full of opportunities—is exactly what this neighborhood offers. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Amy Richards: I definitely feel safe here. There's a real sense of watchfulness in the neighborhood—people look out for each other, and there's always someone around if you need help. I've never had any issues with crime or anything like that, which is something I really appreciate, especially as a mother. Knowing that Lily can ride her bike around the block without me worrying about her safety gives me peace of mind. I think part of that safety comes from the community spirit we have here. We know our neighbors, and that makes a big difference. It's not just about locks and alarms; it's about trust and familiarity. I feel like this neighborhood has my back, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Amy Richards: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, the sense of community is something I truly value. We have block parties, holiday decorations, and even a neighborhood watch group that meets once a month. It's comforting to know that if something happens, there are people who care and will help. But like any place, there are challenges too. Sometimes the pace of life here feels a bit slow, and I can get frustrated when things don't change as quickly as I'd like. There are also moments when I feel like I'm stretched thin trying to keep up with work, parenting, and being involved in the community. But overall, I think the good outweighs the bad. I've built a life here that I'm proud of, and I believe in the future for Lily and our family. This neighborhood has given me roots, and I'm grateful for that.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how deeply connected I am to the people and place that have shaped my life. Talking about Mark, Lily, and our family brought up so many emotions—pride, gratitude, and a sense of purpose. It also made me realize how much my choices, like pursuing education and building a stable career, have contributed to the life I have today. When I discussed my neighborhood, it was like revisiting the sense of safety and community that I value so much. I've always believed that where you live plays a big role in who you become, and I feel lucky to be part of a place that supports not just me, but also my family. It's comforting to know that I'm not just raising Lily in a safe environment, but also in a community that feels like home. These conversations helped me reflect on how much I appreciate the people and the place that have been part of my journey.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Amy Richards: A typical week for me is pretty full, but it's also pretty structured. I usually start my week on Monday with Lily's school drop-off, then head to work. I work a standard 9-to-5 at a local business management firm, so my days are pretty consistent during the week. After work, I pick up Lily from daycare and we have dinner at home. Mark usually helps with getting Lily ready for bed, and I try to read to her every night—it's one of my favorite moments of the day. On Tuesdays and Thursdays, I volunteer at the library, helping with storytime and organizing book donations. Wednesdays are usually the busiest day for me because I have a meeting at work in the morning and then I have to run a few errands before picking up Lily. Fridays are a bit more relaxed, and we often have family dinners with my parents or go out for a walk in the park. Weekends are for family time—Lily has her little playdates, and Mark and I try to do something fun together, whether it's a movie night or a trip to the museum. It's not always perfect, but I love the rhythm of it. It keeps me grounded and reminds me of the life I want for Lily—full of love, learning, and small, happy moments.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Amy Richards: I work full time at a local business management firm as a project coordinator. My job involves managing schedules, coordinating between different departments, and making sure that our clients' needs are met efficiently. I work Monday through Friday, from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., which gives me a good balance between work and family life. I've been in this role for about five years now, and I've really grown into it. It's not always easy—there are days when I'm juggling deadlines and family responsibilities, and I have to be pretty organized to keep everything running smoothly. But I enjoy the challenge, and I feel like my work contributes to the stability of our family. Plus, I've been able to advance a bit in my career, which is something I'm proud of. It's funny, though—I never thought I'd end up in business management. I was always more of a numbers person, but I've learned to love the people side of things too. It's rewarding to see how my work helps others, and I feel like I'm making a difference in my own way.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Amy Richards: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay balanced. I try to wake up early most mornings, around 6:30, to have some quiet time before the day gets going. I usually make coffee, read a chapter of a book, and sometimes do a quick yoga session to get my body moving. It's a small way to start the day on my own terms. I also try to cook at least one meal from scratch each week—something my mom taught me, and it's one of the few things I still do that makes me feel connected to her. On the weekends, if I have the time, I like to take a walk around the neighborhood or visit the local farmer's market. It's a nice way to unwind and get a little fresh air. I also have a habit of journaling, though I don't do it every day. It's more of a way to reflect on my thoughts and feelings, especially when life gets busy. I think these little routines help me stay grounded and remind me of the things that matter most—like family, community, and taking time for myself.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Amy Richards: Well, the biggest change to my daily routine has been with Lily starting preschool this fall. It's been a big adjustment for all of us. I used to drop her off at daycare every morning, but now she's in a structured program from 8:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. That means I have a bit more flexibility in the mornings, which I've started using to get a head start on work or do some planning. On the flip side, the afternoons are a bit more unpredictable now—she comes home with stories from her day, sometimes with friends, and sometimes with a little extra energy that needs to be burned off. Mark and I have had to adjust how we divide up the responsibilities, and honestly, it's been a learning curve. But I think it's helping us grow as parents and as a family. It's also given me more time in the evenings to catch up on things I've been putting off, like reading or even just sitting down with a cup of tea and a good book. It's not perfect, but I'm grateful for the little changes that are helping us find a new rhythm.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Amy Richards: Lily's typical weekday during the school year starts early—usually around 7:00 a.m. with breakfast, and then she gets ready for school. She goes to a local elementary school, and her day is pretty structured. She has recess, lunch, and a few subjects throughout the day. After school, she comes home around 3:00 p.m., and that's when the fun begins. She has a few after-school activities: on Mondays and Wednesdays, she goes to a creative arts class where she gets to paint and make crafts. On Tuesdays and Thursdays, she has a soccer team that practices for about an hour. Fridays are usually a lighter day, and she either stays home with me or goes to a playgroup with some of her friends. I love seeing her light up when she talks about her day—whether it's a new friend she made or a drawing she did. It's amazing how quickly she's growing and learning, and I feel so grateful to be part of that journey. It's also been a great way for her to meet other kids and develop her social skills, which is something I really value as a parent.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how deeply connected I am to the people and place that have shaped my life. Talking about Mark, Lily, and our family brought up so many emotions—pride, gratitude, and a sense of purpose. It also made me realize how much my choices, like pursuing education and building a stable career, have contributed to the life I have today. When I discussed my neighborhood, it was like revisiting the sense of safety and community that I value so much. I've always believed that where you live plays a big role in who you become, and I feel lucky to be part of a place that supports not just me, but also my family. It's comforting to know that I'm not just raising Lily in a safe environment, but also in a community that feels like home. These conversations helped me reflect on how much I appreciate the people and the place that have been part of my journey.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Amy Richards: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty lucky. I've always been pretty active, even as a kid—I loved running around the neighborhood and playing outside with my friends. I still try to stay active now, whether it's walking Lily around the block or doing a quick yoga session in the morning. I do have some occasional back pain from lifting Lily or bending over too much, but nothing serious. I try to take care of myself by eating well, getting enough sleep, and making time for exercise. I also go for annual check-ups, and my doctor says I'm in good shape for my age. I think staying healthy is important, especially with a young family—being there for Lily and Mark means making sure I take care of myself too. I don't have any major health issues, but I do try to be mindful of stress, which can sometimes creep in with work and parenting. I've started practicing mindfulness a bit, which has helped me feel more centered. Overall, I feel pretty good, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Amy Richards: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine and the support of my family. I know if I don't take care of myself, it affects everyone around me, especially Lily. So I try to make small, consistent choices—like eating a balanced breakfast, getting enough sleep, and finding time for movement, even if it's just a walk with Lily. What makes it harder is the stress that comes with juggling work, parenting, and trying to stay involved in the community. There are days when I feel like I'm running on empty, and I have to remind myself to pause and breathe. I've started setting aside a few minutes each evening to just sit quietly and reflect, which helps me reset. It's not always easy, but I know that taking care of my health is one of the best ways I can show up for the people I love.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Amy Richards: In the past two years, I haven't had any major health issues, but there was a time when I struggled with some persistent lower back pain. It started after I was helping Mark move some furniture in our new home, and I overextended myself lifting a heavy box. At first, I thought it was just a minor strain, but the pain lingered for a few weeks and made it hard to get up in the morning or bend down to pick up Lily. I finally made an appointment with my doctor, and she said it was probably due to muscle strain and recommended physical therapy. I went for a few sessions, and it helped a lot. I also started being more mindful of how I lift things and made sure to take breaks when I'm doing chores around the house. It was a reminder that even small things can take a toll on your body, especially when you're juggling so much. I'm glad I addressed it early, and now I feel much better. It's one of those things that made me realize how important it is to listen to my body and take care of myself, even when life gets busy.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Amy Richards: Honestly, I can't say the back pain ever really stopped me from doing what I needed to do, but it did make me more aware of how much I push myself without realizing it. There were a few days when I was exhausted and felt like I wasn't doing enough for Lily or my job, and that stress made the pain worse. I had to learn to slow down a little and ask for help when I needed it—whether it was Mark helping with chores or just taking a few minutes to rest. It was a tough lesson, but it taught me that taking care of myself isn't selfish; it's necessary. I think that's something I want to pass on to Lily too, so she knows that it's okay to take a break and take care of herself when life gets overwhelming.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Amy Richards: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—there's been a lot of growth, but also some challenges. On the positive side, I've really come to appreciate the little moments more. Being with Lily every day, watching her learn and grow, has been incredibly rewarding. I've also found more balance in my own life, whether it's through my morning yoga practice or setting aside time to read. That said, there have been moments of stress and overwhelm, especially with work and parenting responsibilities. I think the pandemic really changed the way I see things, even though we've been back to a more normal routine now. It made me realize how important it is to be present and to take time for myself and my family. I've also been more intentional about my relationships—with Mark, with my parents, and with my friends. I feel like I've grown more as a person in the past year than I have in a long time, and I'm grateful for that.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes and health reminded me of how much life has shifted in the past year, especially with Lily starting preschool and the adjustments that came with it. It also made me reflect on how important it is to take care of myself, not just for my own well-being, but for the people I love. I've learned that even small changes, like getting more rest or finding time for mindfulness, can make a big difference in how I feel and how I show up for my family. It's been a journey of growth, and I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned along the way.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Amy Richards: I think I've been pretty lucky in that regard. I've had some days where I felt overwhelmed or stressed, especially with the demands of work and being a mom, but I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in a way that required professional help. That said, I've been more aware of my mental health lately. I've started setting aside time each day to check in with myself—whether it's through journaling, a short walk, or just sitting quietly with a cup of tea. I think it's important to recognize when you're feeling off and to take steps to address it before it builds up. I've also been more open with Mark about how I'm feeling, and that's helped a lot. He's been a great support, and I think that kind of openness is something I want to model for Lily as she grows up. I believe in the power of talking things through and taking care of your mind just as much as your body.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Amy Richards: For our family, the past year has been a mix of growth and adjustment. Mark and I have been working on strengthening our communication, especially with the added challenges of parenting and work. We've had some really meaningful conversations about our goals and how we want to support each other moving forward. Lily has been such a joy to watch—she's becoming more independent, and it's amazing to see her confidence grow. She's also started asking more questions about everything, which keeps me on my toes, but I love that she's curious and eager to learn. My parents have been a steady presence in our lives, and I feel so grateful for their support. Even though Ethan is far away, we've been making an effort to stay connected, and I think that's helped us all feel more grounded. Overall, I'd say we're in a good place, and I feel like we're all learning and growing together.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Amy Richards: For me, religion has always been an important part of my life, though I wouldn't say I'm deeply involved in church services or rituals on a weekly basis. I was raised Protestant, just like my parents, and I still find comfort in my faith. It's not something I think about every day, but during tough times or moments of reflection, I turn to prayer or scripture for guidance. I believe in the values my faith teaches—like kindness, forgiveness, and community—and I try to live by them in my daily life. I also find that being part of a church community has given me a sense of belonging, especially as a mother. It's comforting to know that there are people who share similar beliefs and who are there to support one another. I don't think of myself as particularly spiritual, but I do believe that faith has played a role in shaping who I am and how I approach life's challenges.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Amy Richards: To be honest, I'm not a big social media user. I have a Facebook account mostly to stay in touch with family and old friends, especially Ethan, since we don't see each other often. I follow a few pages related to parenting and community events in Des Moines, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or comparing my life to others. I think it's easy to get caught up in that, and I've seen how it can affect people's moods and self-esteem. For me, I prefer keeping things more personal and grounded. I do post the occasional photo of Lily or a family event, just to share those moments with people who matter. It's not about the numbers or likes—it's about staying connected in a meaningful way. I think that's something I want to teach Lily too, so she knows that real connections are more important than online validation.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Amy Richards: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really turned to social media for support during tough times. I've always found comfort in my family, my faith, and the people I know in real life. That said, I do appreciate the way Facebook has helped me stay connected with my parents and Ethan, especially when life gets busy and we don't have time to visit. I've seen posts from friends who are going through hard times, and sometimes I'll send them a message just to check in or offer help if I can. But for me, support has always come from the people I see every day—Mark, Lily, my parents, and the friends I've known for years. I think it's important to have that real-world support system, and I'm grateful for the ones I have.

Going through the interview questions about my health and recent experiences reminded me of how much life has changed in the past year, especially with Lily starting preschool and the adjustments that came with it. It also made me reflect on how important it is to take care of myself, not just for my own well-being, but for the people I love. I've learned that even small changes, like getting more rest or finding time for mindfulness, can make a big difference in how I feel and how I show up for my family. It's been a journey of growth, and I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned along the way.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Amy Richards: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have fluctuated, especially with Lily starting preschool and the new routines that came with it. There were times when I felt like I was constantly switching gears—between work, parenting, and trying to stay involved in the community. But I've been working on developing better coping strategies. One thing that's helped me is setting aside a few minutes each morning for mindfulness, even if it's just deep breathing or a short meditation. I've also found that talking things through with Mark has been really important. He's become my go-to person for venting or just having a calm conversation when I need it. I've also started journaling more, which helps me process my thoughts and emotions. It's not always easy, but I've come to realize that stress is a part of life, and it's how I respond to it that matters most. I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to recognize when I need to slow down and take a step back.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Amy Richards: In terms of making ends meet, I'd say our budget is pretty tight but manageable. My salary covers most of our expenses, and Mark's income helps with the rest. Our biggest expenses last month were rent, which is about $1,200, and groceries, which usually run around $600 to $700 depending on what Lily needs for school and activities. We also have car payments, insurance, and a few other bills like utilities and internet. One of the things I've had to be careful with is saving for Lily's future—like her college fund or extracurricular activities. We also set aside a small amount each month for emergencies, just in case. It's not always easy, especially with the cost of living here in Des Moines, but we've learned to be pretty frugal. I try to plan our meals ahead of time, use coupons when I can, and avoid unnecessary expenses. It's a balancing act, but I feel like we're doing okay. I also have some savings from when I was working part-time during college, which has helped a bit. Overall, I'm grateful that we're not struggling, and I know that with careful planning, we can keep our heads above water.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Amy Richards: Our household spent around $3,500 last month, which is pretty much in line with what we usually spend. The majority of that goes toward rent, groceries, and utilities, which are the basics we can't really cut back on. We also have car payments and insurance, which add up, and then there's the cost of Lily's preschool and after-school activities. I've been trying to be more intentional about budgeting, like setting aside a specific amount each month for savings and emergencies. It's not always perfect, but I feel like we're managing. I think the key for us has been prioritizing what's most important—like Lily's education and our home life—while being mindful of where we can save. I also try to cook at home as much as possible and limit eating out, which helps keep the grocery bill in check. It's a balancing act, but I feel like we're doing okay, and I'm grateful for the stability we have.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Amy Richards: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment in a building that's just a few blocks from the park where Lily loves to play. Renting was the practical choice for us when we first started our family—it gave us flexibility, especially since we weren't sure how long we'd be in Des Moines or how our careers would develop. Plus, with Mark's income and my salary, buying a home felt like a stretch at the time. We've been in this apartment for about three years now, and while it's not the biggest place, it's cozy and has everything we need. We've made it feel like home with some plants, a few family photos, and a small reading nook that Lily adores. I think renting has allowed us to focus more on building our savings and making sure we're financially stable for the future, especially when it comes to Lily's education and our long-term goals. It's not perfect, but it works for us right now.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Amy Richards: Over the past year, our bills have had their ups and downs, just like the seasons. In the winter, our heating bill went up quite a bit, which was a surprise since we're used to the colder months here in Iowa. We also had to budget more for Lily's winter clothes and supplies for her preschool, which added a few extra dollars to our monthly expenses. Then, come spring, we started spending more on outdoor activities—like buying a new bike for her and signing her up for a spring soccer league. Summer brought its own set of costs, like buying sunscreen, swim gear, and a few weekend trips to the lake with friends. And of course, the holidays were always a bit more expensive—decorations, gift exchanges with family, and a nice dinner for Christmas Eve. I've learned to plan a little extra each month to cover these seasonal changes, and it's helped us stay on track. It's not always easy, but I think being aware of these patterns has made us more prepared and less stressed about unexpected costs.

Going through the interview questions about my family and recent experiences has made me reflect on how much growth and change have happened in the past year. It's been a time of adjustment, especially with Lily starting preschool and the new routines that came with it, but I've also found more balance in my life—whether it's through mindfulness, journaling, or simply being present with my family. I've come to appreciate the importance of mental and emotional well-being, and I'm learning to be kinder to myself when things get overwhelming. It's also reminded me how much I value the support of my family, friends, and faith, and how those connections help me navigate life's challenges. I feel grateful for the people in my life and the lessons I've learned along the way.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Amy Richards: I actually do save, though it's not always a lot. We have a small savings account that we try to contribute to each month, even if it's just a few dollars. It's more of a habit than a huge amount, but I think it's important to have that safety net, especially with the unpredictability of life. I also set aside some money each paycheck for emergencies, like car repairs or unexpected medical costs. I've learned that even small amounts add up over time, and it gives me peace of mind knowing we're not completely caught off guard. I also try to be mindful of our spending habits—like avoiding impulse purchases or eating out too often. It's not always easy, but I believe that saving, even in small ways, is a form of planning for the future. I want Lily to grow up knowing that it's important to be responsible with money, and I think setting an example by saving ourselves is one way to do that.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Amy Richards: In the last year, I've been saving more intentionally for both the future and for unexpected expenses. We've been setting aside a portion of each paycheck for Lily's college fund, even if it's just a small amount each month. It's something I want to do for her, so she has options when she's ready for college. At the same time, we've also been building up an emergency fund, which has been especially important after my back injury last year. I learned how quickly things can change, and having that financial cushion gives me more peace of mind. I also try to save for bigger things, like a down payment on a house, but that feels a bit further off for now. For now, I'm focused on being responsible with what we have and making sure we're prepared for whatever comes next.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Amy Richards: My occupation has been as a project coordinator at a local business management firm, and it's been both challenging and rewarding. The most important activities involve managing schedules, coordinating between different departments, and ensuring that our clients' needs are met efficiently. I spend a lot of time communicating with team members, setting deadlines, and making sure everything runs smoothly. One of the things I love most about my job is the variety—it's never the same day twice. Some days are spent in meetings, others are focused on problem-solving or helping clients find better ways to streamline their operations. I also enjoy the people side of things; I've built strong relationships with my coworkers and clients over the years, and that makes the work feel more meaningful. It's not always easy, especially when juggling work with family life, but I feel like my job contributes to the stability of our family and gives me a sense of purpose. I never imagined I'd end up in business management, but I've learned to appreciate the skills I've developed and the impact I can have in my own way.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Amy Richards: I usually work around 40 hours a week, Monday through Friday, from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. It's a standard full-time schedule, and while it can be demanding, I've learned to manage my time so that I can still be present for Lily and Mark. I try to be efficient with my workday so that I don't bring stress home with me. There are days when I'm swamped with deadlines or meetings, and I have to work a bit late, but I make it a point to leave on time whenever I can. I've also started using my lunch break to take a short walk or read a bit, which helps me recharge. It's a balance I'm still learning, but I feel like my job gives me the stability I need to support my family, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Amy Richards: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on having a full-time role that allows me to be present for my family, especially with Lily. I did work part-time during college, though—helping out at a local bookstore in the afternoons while I was studying in the mornings. That gave me a sense of independence and responsibility even back then. After college, I took a full-time position at the business management firm, and I've been there ever since. I think having a single, stable job has been important for me, not just for the income, but also for the structure it provides. It helps me feel like I can plan for the future, whether it's for Lily's education or for our family's long-term goals. I've never been one for juggling multiple jobs—it just feels like it would take away from the time I want to spend with Mark and Lily, and I value that more than anything.

Going through the questions about my stress, emotional coping strategies, and financial situation has made me reflect on how much I've grown over the past year. I used to think that being busy meant I was productive, but now I realize that taking time to breathe, practice mindfulness, and talk things through with Mark has been just as important as the work I do or the money we make. It's been a learning curve, especially with Lily starting preschool and the new routines that came with it, but I've come to appreciate the small moments that help me stay grounded. I've also learned that managing our finances isn't just about numbers—it's about making choices that support our family's well-being and future. I feel more in control of my life now, and I'm grateful for the balance I've found between work, family, and self-care.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Amy Richards: In total, our household made around $6,500 in the past month. That includes my full-time salary and Mark's income from his software engineering job. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our expenses and still set aside some money for savings and emergencies. I've always believed that financial stability is about more than just making money—it's about managing it wisely and being prepared for the unexpected. I'm proud of how we've been able to balance our budget, especially with Lily's needs and our long-term goals in mind. It's not always easy, but I feel like we're on the right track, and I'm grateful for the work we both do to support our family.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Amy Richards: I've been at my current job for about five years now, and I've really grown into the role. The benefits package is pretty standard for a company this size—health insurance, dental, vision, and a 401(k) plan. We also get paid time off, which is something I really appreciate, especially with Lily in preschool. I get about 15 days of vacation a year, and I try to use some of that time for family trips or just a few days to recharge. We also have sick days, which has been helpful, especially when Lily is under the weather or when I need to take care of her. The company also offers some wellness programs, like discounted gym memberships and mental health resources, which I've started taking advantage of. I think having these benefits has made a big difference in my ability to balance work and family life, and I'm grateful for the support my employer provides.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Amy Richards: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a good rapport with my manager, Sarah Mitchell. She's been with the company for over a decade, and she's always been supportive of me, even when I was still finding my footing in the role. She's not one of those managers who micromanages—she trusts her team to do the work and gives us the freedom to problem-solve on our own. That kind of trust has made a big difference in how I approach my job. As for my coworkers, I've built some really strong relationships over the years. We have a good dynamic in our department—everyone is friendly, collaborative, and willing to help each other out when needed. I especially enjoy working with Tom, who I mentioned earlier. He's been a great confidant and a reliable teammate. I think having a positive work environment is just as important as the work itself, and I'm lucky to be in a place where I feel valued and respected.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Amy Richards: My work schedule is pretty predictable, which is something I really appreciate, especially with the demands of being a mom. I work Monday through Friday, from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., and while there are occasional late nights when deadlines are tight, it's mostly consistent. My manager is pretty flexible if I need to adjust my hours for family reasons, which has been a huge help. For example, if Lily is sick or if I need to pick her up early from preschool, I can usually talk to my manager and rearrange my schedule a bit. That kind of flexibility makes a big difference in being able to balance work and family life. I also appreciate that my job doesn't require me to be on call outside of regular hours, which gives me a clear boundary between work and home. It's not always perfect, but I feel like I have a good balance, and that predictability helps me plan better for my family and my own well-being.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Amy Richards: Overall, I feel pretty stable about my financial situation. It's not extravagant, but it's enough to cover our needs and give us some room to plan for the future. I know we're not wealthy, but I also know that we're not struggling, and that gives me a sense of security. I think the key for us has been being intentional with our money—prioritizing what matters most, like Lily's education and our home life, while also setting aside a little for savings and emergencies. I've learned that financial stability isn't just about making more money; it's about managing what you have wisely. I'm grateful for the work I do and for Mark's job, and I feel like we're building a solid foundation for our family. There are days when I worry about the future, especially with the rising cost of living and the uncertainty of the economy, but I try to focus on what we can control. I believe in our ability to adapt and make the best of what we have, and I feel confident that we're on the right path.

Going through the interview questions about my bills, savings, and work schedule has made me reflect on how much I've learned about managing my finances and time over the past year. It's been a journey of balancing work, family, and personal well-being, and I've come to appreciate the importance of being intentional with both my money and my time. I used to think that being busy meant I was productive, but now I realize that taking time to breathe, practice mindfulness, and talk things through with Mark has been just as important as the work I do or the money we make. It's been a learning curve, especially with Lily starting preschool and the new routines that came with it, but I've come to appreciate the small moments that help me stay grounded. I've also learned that managing our finances isn't just about numbers—it's about making choices that support our family's well-being and future. I feel more in control of my life now, and I'm grateful for the balance I've found between work, family, and self-care.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Amy Richards: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked at a local factory, and my mom was a school secretary. They both had pretty stable jobs, and while they weren't making a lot of money, they always made sure we had what we needed. I remember my mom working long hours, sometimes coming home tired but always making time to help with homework or listen to me when I had something on my mind. My dad was more hands-on with things like fixing things around the house or taking me on little trips to the park. I think their work ethic really shaped me—it taught me the value of hard work and responsibility. I also remember how they always encouraged me to do well in school, even though they didn't have a lot of formal education themselves. I think that's one of the reasons I felt motivated to go to college—it was a way to honor their sacrifices and give myself more opportunities.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Amy Richards: My mom was a school secretary, and her most important activities involved managing the front office, handling communications between teachers and parents, and making sure the school ran smoothly on a day-to-day basis. She was the first person you saw when you walked into the building in the morning, and she was always ready with a smile or a kind word. She also organized events like parent-teacher conferences, open houses, and even the annual school carnival. I remember her staying late after school to help teachers with paperwork or to make sure everything was set up for the next day. She had a real passion for education and believed in the importance of community, which is something I carry with me today. My dad worked at a local factory, and his most important duties involved operating machinery and ensuring that production lines ran efficiently. He was a very hands-on worker, and I remember him coming home with calloused hands but always with a story about the day's work. He took pride in his job, even though it wasn't glamorous, and he always made sure we had what we needed. Their work shaped my understanding of responsibility and the value of hard work, and I think that's why I was so determined to go to college and build a stable career of my own.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Amy Richards: My mom worked for the Des Moines Public School District, and my dad worked for a local manufacturing company called Midwest Fabrications. Both of them were part of the kind of businesses that kept our community running—my mom in the education sector and my dad in the industrial sector. My mom's job was more about people, and she always said she loved being the first face that parents and students saw when they walked into the school. She made sure that everyone felt welcome and supported, and I think that's why she was so respected by both the teachers and the parents. My dad's job was more hands-on, and while it wasn't always easy, he took pride in the work he did. He would come home with stories about the machines he operated and the challenges he faced on the factory floor. I remember him saying that even though the work was repetitive, it was important because it helped support our family and the people in our community. Both of them worked hard, and I think that's one of the reasons I grew up valuing education and responsibility so much. Their jobs weren't glamorous, but they were steady, and that gave me a sense of security growing up.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Amy Richards: I hope that in a few years, my life will still be rooted in the same values that have guided me—family, community, and personal growth. I hope that Lily is growing into a kind, curious, and confident young woman who feels empowered to make her own choices and follow her passions. I also hope that Mark and I continue to build a life together that's filled with love, laughter, and shared experiences. I'd like to see us maybe buy a home someday, not because we need it, but because it would be a symbol of the life we've built and the stability we've created for our family. I also hope that I continue to grow in my career, maybe take on more leadership roles or even start mentoring others in the way that Mrs. Thompson mentored me. I want to be someone who makes a positive impact, not just in my own life, but in the lives of those around me. And I hope that no matter how life changes, I always remember to take time for myself, to be present for my family, and to appreciate the little things that make life meaningful.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Amy Richards: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with my family, my community, or the people who have supported me along the way. I think relationships are the foundation of everything else. I value the time I get to spend with Mark and Lily, the way we laugh together, grow together, and support each other through the ups and downs. I also value the sense of belonging I feel in this neighborhood, where people know each other and look out for one another. I think that kind of community is rare, and I'm grateful for it. On a personal level, I value growth—whether it's through learning something new, facing a challenge, or simply becoming a better version of myself. I also value the small, everyday moments—the sound of Lily reading a story, the smell of coffee in the morning, or the way the sun feels on my face when I take a walk. Life is made up of these little things, and I try to be present for them as much as I can. I think if I had to sum it up, I value love, connection, and the quiet moments that make life feel meaningful.

Going through the interview questions about my stress, emotional coping strategies, and financial situation has made me reflect on how much I've grown over the past year. I used to think that being busy meant I was productive, but now I realize that taking time to breathe, practice mindfulness, and talk things through with Mark has been just as important as the work I do or the money we make. It's been a learning curve, especially with Lily starting preschool and the new routines that came with it, but I've come to appreciate the small moments that help me stay grounded. I've also learned that managing our finances isn't just about numbers—it's about making choices that support our family's well-being and future. I feel more in control of my life now, and I'm grateful for the balance I've found between work, family, and self-care.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a meaningful journey of reflection, reminding me of the many paths that have shaped who I am today. From my childhood in Des Moines, to the pivotal decision to go to college, to the support I received from mentors like Mrs. Thompson, each moment has contributed to the life I now live with Mark and Lily. It's amazing how the choices I made—like pursuing education and building a stable career—have created the foundation for the family and community I cherish. Talking about my neighborhood, my job, my health, and my financial situation has helped me see how interconnected these aspects of life are. I've come to appreciate the importance of balance, whether it's between work and family, or between self-care and responsibility. This reflection has also reminded me of the people who have supported me along the way—my parents, my friends, and the community that has always felt like home. I'm grateful for the journey I've been on, and I'm excited for the future, knowing that I have the strength, love, and values to continue growing and making a positive impact in my family's and my own life.
